segments.text: The first series of questions I should like to ask have to do with your academic background and your interest in oceanography.
How and when did you acquire an interest in marine biology and oceanography?
Well, how far back do you want to go?
Wherever the beginning is.
Really, I would describe it to my mother, who grew up in Gloucester, and they come from a fishing family.
And ever since I was born, that's the age of three months, we would spend summers in an island in Maine and explore the beaches.
And she had the training and background to explain primarily the biology, not necessarily the physical oceanography of the beaches.
And we did that until really I went off to school for 16 years.
We would spend the entire summer from the end of school to the beginning until Labor Day.
So I would say that was really the very beginning.
Yeah.
You're from Massachusetts, right?
Yeah.
OK. Why did you choose the University of Washington?
Well, of course, the time that I would be going to school, this was wartime in the 40s.
And the University of Washington, I didn't come to some time.
I spent some time at sea.
This was my interest in being at sea.
And I was a graduate of the Massachusetts Maritime Academy, in which we studied meteorology.
And it really wasn't considered oceanography, but it was the science of the sea, marine science.
And at the end of the war, well, let me say during the war, I worked as a ship's officer with the Army Transportation Corps.

graduated from the academy with a commission as ensign in the navy but rather than go right into the navy i went into the large ship area of army transportation corps at the end of the war i had some navy duty and became involved in submarines so i i have a master's license in the

maritime service and acquired that at age 23 and felt that I had explored that and I had some tour in the Navy qualified submarine officer and felt that I had explored that and was interested in a further in the study of the science of the sea oceanography.
This was available to naval officers at the Naval Postgraduate School which was attached or had some role with Scripps and
I was interested in that program, but wasn't eligible for it.
So I got out of the Navy.
And one of the ship's officers' father was the provost at Rhode Island, University of Rhode Island.
And he wrote to me and told me about the Dr. Fishers, the two Dr. Fishers at Rhode Island.
And he recommended that I go to the University of Washington because it was a new school, and they were starting
a new program exclusively in oceanography.
So it came as a result of the Navy and a recommendation from the provost at the University of Rhode Island.
You arrived here at Washington about the same time Fleming got here to establish the school.
Just after.
He arrived in 51 and I was here in 53, early in 53.
And you stayed until 55.
Did you go to school full-time between 1953 and 1955?
Yes, actually, I stayed until 1957.
Okay.
You must have worked on a Ph.D. for a while then.
According to my notes, your master's degree is 1955.
Well, I finished the work then, but I didn't...
What happened is that the university at the time had an extensive contract with this center.
At this time, it was the Bureau of Commercial Fisheries.
And I worked on that, and I was interested in it.
So I didn't finish the degree work for the master's degree.
I didn't go through the formalities of obtaining it and got involved in an extensive ocean program here.
And the degree made very little difference to the people here.
But when I wanted to go on to get the PhD,
People insisted that I clear up the master's degree, so I did.
And so I've been here directly from the University of Washington since 57.
But I studied at the university and at Oregon State University.
Right.
Your PhD is from Oregon State.
Yes.
I'm sort of intrigued about the close relationship between physical oceanography, meteorology, and marine biology that you put together.
Was there any particular reason for that?
Yes, because...
All of my training in the Navy and the submarines was more of a physical nature, not a biological nature.
And I wasn't specifically interested in the unique, finite studies of biology.
But having come from the center and realizing I was coming back from the center in my third option, I took marine biology.
Because in the period I was here, I felt, and this decision was made before I came here, that I was interested in
in what you would call today's sort of ecosystem approach.
It was the total study of a segment of the ocean, large or small, not the individual study of any one discipline.
So that's why the two came together.
The physical oceanography and the meteorology were extensions of my other previous studies.
And the biology came from the center here, the interest in it.
And so you would suggest then that your interest in marine biology then develops after you
or Ole Miss jobs for practical interest increasing.
What did you first do when you went to work here?
Well, I came here right in charge of the oceanography program.
They didn't have any field studies here.
The center was established as an exploratory fishing base that had a fishing vessel and a fishing class that just went fishing.
And they had what we called at that time a biological laboratory, which did research.
But it was primarily research on salmon in the streams, the Columbia River and in the Alaskan streams.
It did not have what you'd call an ocean research program.
And so in 1953, which was while I was studying, the International North Pacific Fisheries Commission was formed, which was a transocean study of the distribution and movement of salmon.

And in order to study this, then we developed here at the center an operational program to catch salmon at sea and to make the environmental measurements that tried to assess what it was in the sea that may be guiding the movements of the salmon.
So as I said, I worked on this program at the university for a year.
and the contract of the university was referred back to the laboratory.
The laboratory established the staff, and I headed it up.
So I've been the head of the first and the only oceanographic program here since the center started.
What direction have you tried to take your program?
I realize it would be largely practical because that's what oceanography is about in terms of government.
What else did you do?
What did you have in mind doing, constructing?
Well, I think there are really three phases.
At that time, we knew very little about the North Pacific Ocean.
There were very few cruises that had been conducted.
The University of Washington had just the year before entered out into the ocean.
They were mainly a Puget Sound study.
Wayne Bird hadn't started his program at Oregon State at that time.
There was no program at the University of Alaska.
We were basically the only group.
This was a tri-nation treaty, Canada, Japan, the United States.

And so between the three of us, the three groups, we kind of split the northern North Pacific Ocean into three areas, the western part by the Japanese, the central part, which we took over, and the eastern part in the Gulf of Alaska by the Canadian group under Dr. Tully.
And our first attempt was really to just define what was the steady state, what were the mean conditions over a year's time.
And having put in the pieces and
were able to show the continuity of the ocean from the western side to the eastern at subsurface levels.
There had always been charts of temperature, surface temperature, surface salinity.
The observations of depth were not there.
There were a number of questions that we couldn't answer.
And having defined that, then we looked at the annual time changes.
And at that point, we started relating them to the distribution of movements in Sandman.
And we were quite successful, I think, in that.
And we've gone from that into what you might call a historical study.
We were so caught up with the individual cruises and processing the data from individual cruises, we really didn't look at the ocean as an entity.
And having gone back and looked at 10, 20, or 30 years where the data we find long-term changes that were masked by our individual yearly cruises,
And so we've gone from that point into really a model study.

Now we're in numerical models of the whole system, how the wind stress affects the flow and how this affects the deeper layers and what years there were unusual stresses in certain areas that would divert systems that we assume that the fish in the ocean have followed.
So it's kind of a complete study all the way through from just basic
Observations to monitoring to investigation to numerical models, which is where we are now.
And I assume you'll stay with that a while.
What do you propose for the immediate future?
At the present time, we're involved in two.
areas.
One is numerical models that permit us to see in terms of one month to several months ahead what the conditions will be in the ocean, and we hope to relate that to fishing strategy.
And the other is what I really had in mind when I came here, and that's ecosystems models.
In this, we are handling the coastal zone, the shallow shelf of the eastern Bering Sea, although it's
500 kilometers wide and around the Gulf.
And this is the interactions of the various components, marine components in the system, and how they react to changes in the environment.
So it's sort of a physical and a biological.
So you see, I'm still right in my niche here.
Now, I have a series of specific questions I'd like to ask you to comment on, if you could, or would, really.
And primarily, they concern your work.
And these questions are primarily designed to help probably explain further what you're doing.
How accurate are we in the stage of using physical circulation data in describing the distribution of marine fisheries such as salmon?
Well, I don't know.

when you say accuracy i think we have shown that the area in which salmon are found in the oceans are bounded by physical processes or physical physical chemical boundaries as we see them uh fronts so to speak and uh we see areas in which uh
The separation of salmon that will return to Asia and salmon that will return to North America follow these boundaries or these systems.

But a great deal more work has to be done in this regard because there still is the feeling by the biologists that there is an extensive intermingling that it's very difficult to make any sense out of at this time because of the limited observations you have.
Perhaps I can clarify that a little more.
My feeling is that
Most of the salmon fishing is done at night, and this is the time in which salmon come to the surface.

And if you take this catch and identify the salmon from heuristics or morphological characteristics or serological characteristics, you're able to show that this is, at times, a mixture of Asian and North American.
This is usually at the boundaries of these fronts.
And so the biologist is quick to assume that this indicates
mixing and therefore a random distribution.

My feeling is that there is a separation in strata, whereas although they're at the surface at night feeding and we catch them at night at gill nets, that during the daytime and as they move, that they move as discrete units and they can be separated.
So it's our fishing method of capture that I think prevents us from this unique separation that I sincerely believe exists in the ocean.
Well, in a way, you're
Anticipating my next question.
Modeling, particularly marine productive models and biological modeling.
If I may say so, sort of the end thing now for marine biologists to do.
How accurate are they, and how satisfied are you with them?
Well, at this time, of course, this is a very controversial area, but I can answer your question very directly if
If you took a group of people, there are those people who feel that man is never going to be able to model nature to the other people that feel that man can do it very capably.

There are still people that are so confused as to how to model, say, primary production, which is just the plant production, and their inability really to see all the facets of that, that they can't see how that you can go on to the next step.
But

I think that we here at the Center have made great strides for several reasons, one of which we have limited our present study to the eastern Bering Sea shelf, which is not a huge oceanic area having tremendous depth.
It's rather a closed system.
As you can see, it's bounded by the Alaskan Peninsula and bounded by the Asian continent.
So you really can treat that as an ecosystem.
And I think this is rather unique.
Now, what we have done
is not to start with primary production, where most modelists do.
And they base it that you can't have the next level unless you have a certain amount.
There's usually an order of magnitude decrease as you go up the food web or food chain.
But we have started right with the fish and found out what it is that they require to eat and the amounts and what the amounts of forage that what they're eating require.
and built an ecosystem that way, and we think it's quite remarkable.
What we have done is taken eight components, two fish, two mammals, two birds, and two forms of plankton that interact and are the dominant forms in their area.
In some cases, they represent 90% of a specific biomass.
The fish, for instance, is pollock.
Pollock constitutes 90% of the biomass in the eastern Bering Sea.
These are eaten by seals.
euphosids at some times and they're cannibalistic at other times.
And you get a balance this way.
You get tremendous insight into the ecosystem of the area.
And I'll just point out two things because I could talk for several hours on that.
The two things are that we find that a low percentage of the phytoplankton is really consumed in the eastern Bering Sea.
It's not limiting.
Probably only 30% is utilized by the
the planktonic forms that are forage organisms.
The rest just drops to the bottom and is assumed by the benthos.
So right away, somebody dealing with the primary production model is off base.
And the other thing is that we're finding interactions of the juvenile fish are very significant.
And this is an area that no one studies.
The oceanographers will study phytoplankton, zooplankton, and sometimes ichthyoplankton by itself.
And we, as a center, study only the commercial phase with great big huge nets.
And what we're finding is the bulk of the biomass is in the juvenile fish who are eaten and being eaten in a tremendous cannibalistic and
Sort of a sequence of events, and we're finding out that indeed starvation must play a very important role in the whole system there.
No one has ever put their hand on before because they just drop out, fall to the bottom, and nobody really catches them.
You mean the fish starvation?
Yes, starvation of the fish themselves.
There are areas and times where they just can't do that, can't find enough forage to survive.
So what we've done is this is a lot of this preliminary modeling has been done by Tyler here, who works with me.
And so what we have is these eight components, and we follow them through a year cycle, filling in gaps where the data are not available, and balance the system out.
And we've been able to balance it out for five years.
And since the mammals don't get tremendously fat or the fish don't die out, we're looking for an equilibrium that all of these things can interact.
And in that sense, I think this is
Just a tremendous asset to the center that we're just exploiting.
I think it's absolutely necessary that in fisheries management and understanding the ecosystem of the eastern Bering Sea that people understand these things.
And we are astonishing people on a month-to-month basis as things that invariably people say, well, you know, I always thought that was true, but I never knew how to approach it.
So my answer is that if man is ever able to,
duplicate nature, which I think will be difficult.
I think this is one of the routes to go in the bulk sense that tremendous new bits of information are becoming available.
We have just increased the model from eight components to 25 components in the sense to work in the benthos, and the model becomes very complicated at that point.
And whether we can
deal with the sensitivity of so many interactions.
That's what we're looking at right now.
So I am a strong advocate of this approach, and I think it's working tremendously well in the eastern .
Quite clear.
No one can complain about that.
What sort of experience have you done with drift models in terms of tracing currents?
We've done a considerable amount of work.

in fact probably four or five years worth of work off the washington coast and in the aleutian area and we have actually done some bottom drifter work in the kodiak island area and these of course have tremendous limitations but i still think it's a useful it's a useful exercise and an inexpensive one provided you don't release
literally tens of thousands of these things because they're being accused of being polluted.
Pollution objects, glass drifting on the beaches, are plastic cards that are not biodegradable.
I think when you're studying an area that you don't know where the circulation is, that they're invaluable.
And I think if you're looking at a small area,
that is bounded where you can expect people to return the cards, it's unusually valuable.
But I'm not an advocate of people that just do it because they hope something will happen.
What I'm saying is that you have to...
I think what I'm saying is that most of the exploratory work in drift
object has been done, and there's very little sense to do any more unless you have a very finite project that wants to find out a single answer.
If I release something here at a given time, will it come here in Vancouver Island or here?
But just the huge releases, there's no need for those anymore in our area.
So I would say, yes, we used it, used it effectively, and except for very specific projects, we have passed out of that phase.
Is there any alternative, by the way, to drift models?
Well, of course, it's the only thing that people can say really positive about drift bottles is that they're cheap.
And, of course, the immediate solution and one that has worked out very well is satellite tracking of buoys.
And we were the first to get involved in this in the Pacific Ocean.
We have a paper for a transponding buoy in the Pacific Ocean.
We were the first group, I was, to get a frequency allocated for it.
telemetry buoy work.

And the information is just, well, as they say in Washington, D.C., or did a few years ago, mind-boggling, because what we're seeing is the tremendous complexities of eddies that are part of the general circulation system.
And we have to point out very quickly that our satellite track buoy program didn't get off the ground because at the time we had the buoys
The buoy project was transferred to Bay St. Louis under the Coast Guard.
And all funds in the fishery service dried up for these expensive buoys.
And so we ended up with them in the barn.
We gave everybody our technology.
We worked with NASA and had them tracked with NASA groups in the Bering Sea.
And so we don't have any, well, the first experiment we had, we released buoys right off the coast.
This is an interesting part of the oceanography of the Pacific Ocean.
is that anybody will tell you that the Eastwood flow across the Pacific diverges off the Washington coast, but nobody can give you an explanation or a physical basis for this.
In other words, does it diverge at 40 in the winter and 50 in the summer, or does it fluctuate back and forth?
Nobody can tell you that, and we're only going to find it out by drifting buoy experiments.
But our buoy program,
was just an isolated number of experiments that I really...
I'm not going to take your time to go into, but I would say the recent ones that are done by the OXIEP, this is the Outer Continental Shelf Environmental Program, have been very fantastic.
They have found buoys drifting in the northern Gulf of Alaska where the research is concentrated because that's where they're drilling the oil.
They have found buoys that will...
perform three and four orbits of non-tidal period around some of the lees of these islands in the Gulf.
And I'm talking of something that will occur over 25 or 30 days.
This provides a tremendous concentrating or resting mechanism for migrating salmon and anything else you want.
No one has ever even imagined that this sort of thing would happen.
So I would say the solution is the
the tracking buoys, that we should do more of them as soon as we can.
And I think the results of the ones that have been accomplished by the OXIEP group.
Actually, it's interesting.
Let me just give you a sideline here.
I told you that we developed the buoy and had them here in the mid-1960s.
When OXIEP wanted to deal with drifting buoys here, they had to go to Don Hanson at Miami.
He's at the AOML lab.
And he's the one now that's doing
satellite track buoy experiments in the Gulf of Alaska for the oil company.
And yet, if we had been able to continue with our program 10 years ago, we probably would be doing it.
He has to fly up or send his people all the way across the country to do these experiments, because he's the only one that has experience with the buoys now.
So that's one of the many things that kind of slipped by the wayside, because fisheries have been really reticent to get into an expensive program of environmental studies.
Well, that's a long answer for just drift models, but I thought you might know that.
I know.
I need to know that.
As a matter of fact, I had a question down here written in.
What is a transponding oceanographic buoy?
Because I had no idea what it was.
And what was its function was my second part.
What else do you think needs to be done in terms of this area, oceanographic?
Well, of course, we need a great deal more study.
And really, we don't need a lot more people coming with vessels and ships and instrumentation.
What we need is some real good coordination.
And lots of times, if I get requests from the National Science Foundation to review some of these studies in the Antarctic or some of these other places where
Work has been going on for a long time.
I also find it necessary to put at the bottom, why don't you do some of the studies off your own coast?
And of course, they're considered world oceanographers rather than local.
And by dealing with fisheries and by dealing with governmental problems, I'm really more concerned about local problems than world problems.
And so what we need to do is to pull all of this work together.
I would say that if the United States
marine agencies on this coast spend upwards of $100 million in marine science.
They have this at their disposal.
Whether they spend it in the Arctic or the Antarctic or the Mediterranean Sea, it doesn't matter.
But it's there.
And yet there is no coordinating group.
Fisheries won't coordinate it.
NOAA doesn't seem to want to coordinate it.
The universities have poor coordination.
And a great deal of the money is wasted.
So what we need is
I really don't want to say a committee because everybody abhors committee, but what we need is coordination.
And with coordination, we would be able to answer these problems.
And I can give you an example of that.
We have excellent evidence that there is a northward flow at the shelf edge along our coast, all the way from California right up into the Gulf of Alaska.
There have been no specific measurements.
of this.
There have been a few drift bottle measurements at the surface, a few trog measurements at the surface, a few speculations of geostrophic flow based upon station data.
But this is a very significant flow.
It could affect fisheries and biology tremendously.
and yet there is no coordinated attempt.
People at Oregon State will look at it and then quit, and somebody higher at the University of Washington will look at it when they get a cruise.
And this is what I think we're missing in fisheries.
What we need to know is the integrity of these systems, because this is what will contain a population.
The population will stay in the system and do it.
So I could give you a long list of things.
That is just one.
We need to know the function of the divergence off the coast.
There's tremendous variability, which we have shown in our reports.
A good example is this cold water that comes out of the Otcott Sea just below the depth of winter turnover.
This is about, say, 200 to 300 meters.
There's good evidence that this
Gradually, over a period of five or ten years, we'll move into the Gulf of Alaska and intrude almost onto the shelf.
Well, as this water intrudes on the shelf of the Gulf of Alaska, it will change at least the migration paths, if not the whole distribution of fauna in that area.
And yet, it's been over ten years since we've had anybody that is able to document these conditions at depth.
What kind of cooperative research have you had with Japan, for example?
And what's your opinion of the cooperative research that's being carried on, really, in this area of the northern Pacific?
Well, let me say that, of course, the early studies, the big
A specific study was NORPAC in 1955, in which this was pretty well done by Oscar Setti and Roger Abell and Joe Reed at Scripps.
Setti, of course, was a Bureau of Commercial Fisheries person.
And at that time, they had all kinds of difficulties with the accuracy of their observations and getting them to complete their work.
Then we had EASTROPAC.
Not, let me see, I'm thinking of, well, there was a big study in the Western Pacific that was a little more successful.
And I'm trying to get to the point where, at the present time, the Japanese have tried to join most of the American operations.
And actually, at this time, they have one individual in Japan that sort of rides herd on each one of our
major ocean thrust, so to speak.
They have someone that speaks for IDOE, someone that speaks for probes, which is the processes and resources of the Eastern Bering Sea study.
And so they have, you going to change that?
Sure, please do.
